trans-unit.source: The exception that is thrown when there is an attempt to combine two delegates based on the <xref href="System.Delegate"></xref> type instead of the <xref href="System.MulticastDelegate"></xref> type.
This class cannot be inherited.
Only delegates based on the <xref:System.MulticastDelegate> type can be combined.
Two multicast delegates can be combined using the <xref:System.MulticastDelegate.CombineImpl%2A> method.
<xref:System.MulticastNotSupportedException> uses the HRESULT COR_E_MULTICASTNOTSUPPORTED, which has the value 0x80131514.
For a list of initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.MulticastNotSupportedException>, see the <xref:System.MulticastNotSupportedException.%23ctor%2A> constructors.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.MulticastNotSupportedException"></xref> class.

This constructor initializes the <xref:System.Exception.Message%2A> property of the new instance to a system-supplied message that describes the error, such as "This operation cannot be performed with the specified delegates."
This message takes into account the current system culture.
The following table shows the initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.MulticastNotSupportedException>.
Property
Value
A null reference (`Nothing` in Visual Basic).
The localized error message string.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.MulticastNotSupportedException"></xref> class with a specified error message.
The content of the `message` parameter should be understandable to the user.
The caller of this constructor is required to ensure that this string has been localized for the current system culture.
The following table shows the initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.MulticastNotSupportedException>.
Property
Value
A null reference (`Nothing` in Visual Basic).
The error message string.
The message that describes the error.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.MulticastNotSupportedException"></xref> class with a specified error message and a reference to the inner exception that is the cause of this exception.
An exception that is thrown as a direct result of a previous exception should include a reference to the previous exception in the <xref:System.Exception.InnerException%2A> property.

The <xref:System.Exception.InnerException%2A> property returns the same value that is passed into the constructor, or a null reference (`Nothing` in Visual Basic) if the <xref:System.Exception.InnerException%2A> property does not supply the inner exception value to the constructor.
The following table shows the initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.MulticastNotSupportedException>.
Property
Value
The inner exception reference.
The error message string.
The error message that explains the reason for the exception.
The exception that is the cause of the current exception.
If the inner parameter is not a null reference (`Nothing` in Visual Basic), the current exception is raised in a `catch` block that handles the inner exception.
